title: 107_hr5556
content: The Act is titled the "National Child Protection and Volunteers for Children Improvement Act of 2002". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. Section 5 of the National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to define the term 'qualified State program' as the policies and procedures required to implement the Act, including timely national criminal history background checks and limitations on fees for State background checks. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to designate authorized agencies and qualified entities for national criminal history background check requests. The term 'routinely' is defined as specific percentages of background check requests returned within certain time frames. SEC. 3. STRENGTHENING AND ENFORCING THE NATIONAL CHILD PROTECTION ACT AND THE VOLUNTEERS FOR CHILDREN ACT. Section 3 of the National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to include guidelines for state programs and qualifications for individuals convicted of crimes involving children. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to include guidelines for state programs and qualifications for individuals convicted of crimes involving children. The amendment specifies that the Attorney General must respond to state authorized agencies within 15 business days. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to include guidelines for state programs and qualifications for individuals convicted of crimes involving children. A qualified entity in a state without a qualified program can request a national criminal background check from the Attorney General. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to include guidelines for state programs and qualifications for individuals convicted of crimes involving children. A qualified entity can request a national criminal background check from the Attorney General, who must respond within 20 business days. Amendments allow state authorized agencies to disseminate criminal history records information directly to qualified entities. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to include guidelines for state programs and qualifications for individuals convicted of crimes involving children. Qualified entities can request a national criminal background check from the Attorney General. SEC. 4. DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to allow the Attorney General and state agencies to share criminal history background check records with qualified entities. SEC. 7. OFFICE FOR VOLUNTEER AND PROVIDER SCREENING. The Attorney General will establish an Office for Volunteer and Provider Screening to facilitate national criminal background checks for care providers. The Office will provide guidelines for qualified entities to make fitness determinations based on providers' criminal history. SEC. 5 of the National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to set limits on fees for national criminal fingerprint background checks. The fee for volunteers with qualified entities cannot exceed $5, and for providers employed by or applying to a qualified entity, the fee cannot exceed $18. SEC. 6 focuses on strengthening state fingerprint technology. The Attorney General will establish a model program in each State and the District of Columbia to improve fingerprinting technology. Funds will be provided to purchase Live-Scan technology or electric fingerprint imaging machines. Additional funds will be given to hire personnel for training and information provision in each county. The funding eligibility for states with a qualified program is up to $2,000,000. Appropriations are authorized to improve fingerprint technology and hire data entry personnel in each state and the District of Columbia for fiscal years 2004 through 2008. The funds will remain available until expended. SEC. 7. PRIVACY PROTECTIONS. Information from national criminal fingerprint background checks cannot be altered except for national security reasons. Qualified entities must assign a representative to handle information requests and delete unnecessary information for employment decisions. Any person who releases information from a national criminal fingerprint background check to unauthorized individuals may face criminal penalties, including a fine of $50,000 or imprisonment for up to 1 year. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2008, with funds remaining available until expended.
